item.title: Australia’s Surprising Job Losses Bolster Case for Rate Cuts
item.description: Australia’s economy surprisingly shed jobs in May, though unemployment held steady as fewer people sought work, suggesting a slight loosening of the labor market and bolstering the case for the Reserve Bank to reduce interest rates further.

item.title: Taiwan Seen Holding Benchmark Rate Due to Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Taiwan is likely to hold its benchmark interest rate for the fifth straight quarter as it considers worries about tariffs, the economy and inflation – though a surge in the local currency provides some incentive for a cut.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Chien-Hua Wan

item.title: New Zealand’s Economic Recovery Gathers Pace as Exports Jump
item.description: New Zealand’s economic recovery from a 2024 recession gathered pace in the first quarter as the central bank lowered interest rates and exports surged.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Brazil Lifts Interest Rate to 15% as Robust Economy Fuels Inflation
item.description: Brazil’s central bank raised its key interest rate by a quarter-point and signaled borrowing costs will likely remain steady for a long period as board members gauge the impact of tight policy on inflation and activity.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andrew Rosati

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Brazil headquarters in Brasilia, Brazil, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. Brazilian assets finished the year lagging all major peers, with the real posting its biggest slump since the pandemic shock of 2020 amid mounting skepticism over President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's commitment to fix a ballooning budget deficit.

item.title: Irish Central Bank Cuts Economic Forecast Again on Heightened Uncertainty
item.description: Ireland’s central bank revised down its economic outlook for the second time in a row as heightened geopolitical uncertainty weighs on the small, open economy.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

item.title: Gen Z Drives Britain’s Consumer Confidence to Highest This Year
item.description: UK consumer confidence jumped to its highest level this year, boosted by rising optimism among Generation Z after the latest increase in the minimum wage.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: BOE Set to Hold Rates With Oil Posing New Threat
item.description: The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates at 4.25% on Thursday and signal it is sticking with its one-cut-every-other-meeting approach as officials try to strike a balance between elevated inflation, higher oil prices and a slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

item.title: Fed’s Powell Says Rate Path Unclear But Tariff Impact Is Coming
item.description: There are a lot of unknowns about the outlook for the economy and interest rates, but Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled at least one thing seems certain: Higher prices are coming.

item.title: US Bonds Rally Stalls as Powell Endorses a Patient Fed Approach
item.description: The Treasury market stalled after Federal Reserve officials indicated they’re still on course to deliver two interest-rate reductions this year, despite the risk of resurgent inflation.

item.title: Fed Officials Hold Rates Again, Still See Two Cuts by Year End
item.description: Federal Reserve officials continued to pencil in two interest-rate cuts in 2025, though new projections showed a growing divide among policymakers over the trajectory for borrowing costs as tariffs make their way through the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

item.title: Czech Government Wins Confidence Vote Months Ahead of Election
item.description: The Czech government survived a confidence vote initiated by the opposition over a Bitcoin scandal, shouldering through the turmoil ahead of a parliamentary election scheduled for October.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Petr Fiala, Czech Republic's prime minister, during an interview at the parliament in Prague, Czech Republic, on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024. Fiala, whose government has been among the most vocal in NATO in denouncing the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine, said forcing Kyiv to cede territory will only encourage Vladimir Putin’s war machine.

item.title: Brazil Braces for Thriller Rate Decision as Bank Calls Shift
item.description: On the eve of Brazil’s interest rate decision this week, XP’s Chief Economist Caio Megale agonized over data and policymaker speeches before switching his forecast to a hold from a quarter-point rise. Poring over the same details, ASA economist Leonardo Costa went the opposite way, ditching his bet on steady borrowing costs and calling for a hike instead.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andrew Rosati

item.title: Macklem Warns of Firmer Inflation, Uncertainty About Impact of Tariffs
item.description: Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem reiterated that he sees inflation running hotter than expected, while saying employment appears to be holding up outside of trade-intensive sectors.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Tiff Macklem, governor of the Bank of Canada, during a news conference in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The Bank of Canada held interest rates steady for a second consecutive meeting, but officials said there may be a need to cut borrowing costs if the economy weakens and inflation remains contained as US tariffs strike.

item.title: Chile Holds Rates at 5%, Leaving Timing Open on Future Cuts
